1. Your full name: Ellen Elizabeth White

2. Your address: 7A7

3. Date: 1956

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Maryfield, Ont., Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Alexander Ferguson, farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March 1899

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Portage la Prairie, 1899; Aiden, 1899-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question, if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West? To go to high school.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people, Reading about it?)

"I learned about the real-The relatives coming west before me and doing well."
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? My friends thought it was a good idea to come west and stay with my uncle.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? I traveled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use? I traveled by train from Moose Jaw to Prince Albert via a steamboat.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) We were very friendly to everyone we met.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Redley on the prairie.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Emily's farm.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. I only lived at Redley.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? I didn't earn a living before coming to Western Canada. After coming, I worked on a farm at Redley from 1899-1904 and then moved to Regina in 1901.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My friends thought it was a good idea to come west, they wished I would go.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

I traveled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I traveled by train from Montreal to Toronto to Prince Albert via a self-made horse-drawn sleigh followed by a horse-drawn cart for the journey - the whole trip was very long.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We were very friendly with every group we met. They were helpful and easy to talk to. We had no problems on the way at the famous stations.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Reddy on the Creola Trail.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Family back.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I only lived at Reddy for a month before coming to Saskatoon in 1909 before coming to be homesteaded.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I didn't learn a living before going to school and I learned on a farm at Reddy from 1899-1904. I was married in December 1901.
3. How often did you visit relatives or friends in your old home? Once a week.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I married James H. White at Redden.

21. Did anyone ever come to see you because of your recommendation? Yes, my family came from the east to look up land.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled. They settled at Redden.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? When on the farm at Redden we raised a little by church wagon. It was a muddy road, we used to travel in the house even though we were small children. The horses were the only ones we could ride in the rain. We used to build snowmen most of them stayed overnight but some fell down in the morning. But when we walked to school there was no snow.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

You've traveled to neighbors. We used to walk to the schoolhouse. We had a horse and buggy in Manitoba and back at Redden. Our family always held summer in the house until the school was built in 1912.

S.W. of Emily
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Once a week.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I married James H. White at Redden Dec 26 - 1901

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? Yes, my family came from the east to work up here.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled. They settled at Redden Manitoba in 1899 earlier came on to Godley

Back + Work up here in 1903

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? When on the farm at Redden we used to go little by little in a wagon. We used to drive in gr - was a muskrat road. We would drive in the morning even though they were small, driving to a certain line before sunrise. Then we would go back in the morning. We bought our own horses and we would go back in the morning. But when we would go back in the morning we would go back in the morning. We bought our own horses and we would go back in the morning.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

You've traveled to neighbors. We used to walk. We had a horse and buggy in Manitoba and back at Redden family. At that time we helped run the horses until the school was built in 1912.

S.W. of Godley
25. When was the first car used in the community? The first car I know of was in Saskatoon in 1909. But the first car I remember in the district had a Ford engine in 1910.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.). Yes.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1918.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Initiate all list practices or purchases made by mail order since then? (Please specify.)

We used to send an order to Calgary about 1910 in fall of the year.

We didn't have much money to send.

We never send for groceries, just for clothing underwear etc.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

We got a telephone in fall of 1916 by Bell.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? No, I decided to stay but never got money enough to get back when poor folks earn too hard will sell.

33. When you came to Shakotanon the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? No, I didn't intend to stay here—never got money enough to get back when poor crops came in and milk sell.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1911? What reasons did they give?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did they return?

We have moved away in the 1930s and other times to take their place.

A very important event in my favorite days was the band's playing at the inauguration of our province in 1905.

There was a big celebration in Regina on the Avenue line. We left at 4 a.m. and arrived home late in the evening.

The city was decorated with electric lights all along the streets and the balconies and flags everywhere. The Alexander Hotel near the Grand Hotel and the Royal Alexandra we got a room for the day. The Beemaham crew was in town to work on the long parade with their many animals from foreign lands as well as horses in wagons.

There was a large platform erected with a canopy over it, particularly on the land which is now the museum park. There were a few lumber plants there but none very small. Sir Clifford Sifton and Lady Laurier spoke from the platform as well as some other officials I have forgotten their names.

They had a special float which ended a long day which I enjoyed all until I was tired.
The third day - April 1905

A very important event in my pioneer days was the flags being raised in the inauguration of our province in 1905.

There was a big celebration in Regina on the Canada Line. We left at 4 am and arrived home late in the evening.

The city was decorated with electric lights all along the streets of the station and every where. The Allen's and Harold were the best hotels and they had rooms we got a room for the day. The Beemans came over in town and took us to the long parade with their many animals from farms.

There was a large platform erected and a cannon was fired on the land.

Which is now the Newcastle Park. There were a few people standing there but very small. We visited friends in Lady Smith.

Other friends I have forgotten their names. They had on their clothes on the morning after they heard the good news which ended a long day without any food until it was 2 pm.
